title: @ Riot, How does Riot make their music?

replies.body:
Hey Flying Buntcake!

It depends on the project. We always compose with sample libraries first and then decide if we need live elements. A lot of it depends on how well we're able to create a realistic sound with samples and if we have time to have a recording session. The Snowdown 2015 track that you linked to was entirely computer generated.

Coolio. Do you guys always have a team writing the score and making the finished product for every piece? ( like in the frequencies documentary?) Or is it one person with feedback from a team?
P.S It's amazing what samples can do.
P.S.S. Have you guys ever thought about a sax solo?

Usually it's one person with feedback from the team.
Haven't thought about a sax solo so far :P

Are there any specific ones you have made? ( under your red name it says composer :P)
And thanks for actually reading this all and responding :D

This year's Snowdown is one of them! Warriors, Braum, Ekko, Project, and more.

Actually there was a post a while back introducing the entire team with more info: http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/sound-music/748EyQOB-riot-music-team-update
The Ekko and Project ones were some of the best ever, you're awesome
If you don't mind me asking, what degrees do you have ? ( Im interested in working at Riot but have no idea which discipline and or where to start besides possible jobs)

I'm pretty sure something related to music technology or music in general would be sufficient. But, with anything related to the arts, a portfolio is very important when applying for jobs. So in this instance, your portfolio would consist of anything you have ever worked on related to music composition (scores would be good to show) or music performance (recording or video). I'm not a music major myself, but that is what I've experienced in having to build my portfolio. This is just my conjectures.
